Tang Dynasty, Monk Chengguan of the Great Flower Ornament Monastery on Mount Qingliang
Chapter on Pure Conduct, Chapter 16. There are six reasons for the initial intention. First, the stages are contrasted. Although there was practice before, the intention is in the stages.

Second, the general and specific are contrasted. As before, the self-cultivation of the initial abode only clarifies the mind generated by the conditioned realm, and the superior progress only clarifies diligently making offerings to the Buddha, delighting in abiding in birth and death, etc.;

The self-cultivation of the second abode only generates the ten minds such as the great compassion of benefiting sentient beings, etc., and the superior progress only clarifies chanting and studying much learning, empty tranquility, etc., then the cultivation in the ten abodes is not the same.
Now this pure conduct is cultivated in common by the ten abodes.
Third, the secular and monastic are contrasted. The text says, The assembly of bodhisattvas in all worlds, relying on the TathÄgata's teachings, dyed robes and left home.
The answer extensively clarifies the precepts of acceptance and practice, etc., the previous ten abodes do not distinguish between the monastic and lay paths.

Fourth, it is the relative comparison between the characteristics and the reality. As for the characteristics, it is like the separate practices mentioned above. Since the practices are different, they are the characteristics.

Now, the meaning of this contemplation is that there is nothing to grasp in the body, nothing to be attached to in cultivation, up to accepting the Dharma of no characteristics, contemplating the Dharma of no characteristics, knowing that all dharmas are the self-nature of the mind, and so forth.

Fifth, it is the relative comparison between cause and effect. The question says, How can one attain the purity of pure conduct, from the stage of a bodhisattva to the path of unsurpassed enlightenment?
The initial stage of a bodhisattva is the stage of the ten abodes.
After explaining the stages, fearing that people will seek the causes, it instructs to cultivate this, just as first knowing cessation and later demonstrating the path.

Sixth, the contrast between the title and explanation, which is the general explanation of the previous meaning. It means that at the end of each stage above it says, In order to cause bodhisattvas to understand the Dharma they hear by themselves, without relying on the teachings of others.
This only generally indicates, so now the explanation says:

Being in accord with this contemplation practice, one immediately attains enlightenment from the initial mind, knowing that all dharmas are the self-nature of the mind, and accomplishes the body of wisdom without relying on the realization of others.
The commentary Second, explaining the name is divided into four parts:
First, directly explaining the name; second, revealing the essence; third, concluding the original name; fourth, distinguishing from the previous.
Now, there are three parts:

If translated into this land, it should be called pure conduct, in order to distinguish from the previous, this retains the Sanskrit sound. Second, the true realm is the Sanskrit, explained in terms of the cause.
Third, nirvana is the Sanskrit, explained in terms of cause and effect.

The commentary What is the essence of pure conduct? is the second revealing of the essence.
There are three parts to this:

First, listing three categories; second, from The five practices of nirvana below, contrasting differences and similarities; third, from However, these three below, explaining their characteristics separately.

In the second part, the five practices refer to the five practices of sages in the eleventh chapter on the practice of sages in the Nirvana Sutra, namely the practice of sages, the practice of purity, the practice of heaven, the practice of infants, and the practice of illness.
The commentary says the four immeasurables are also the seven knowledges. The sutra has both of these, and ancient masters also used these two to explain the essence.
The chapter on the practice of purity is in the fifteenth sutra, and the meaning of the four immeasurables will be explained below.
As for the seven knowledges, the sutra says, Good sons!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in the great vehicle of great parinirvÄá¹‡a, abide in the seven good dharmas, and attain the pure practice.
What are the seven?

First, knowing the Dharma; second, knowing the meaning; third, knowing the time; fourth, knowing contentment; fifth, knowing oneself; sixth, knowing the assembly; seventh, knowing the noble and humble.
That text extensively explains, now I will briefly show.
Knowing the Dharma means knowing the twelve divisions of the scriptures.
Knowing the meaning means skillfully knowing the meaning of all written words and languages.
Knowing the time means at such a time one is able to cultivate meditative concentration, at such a time one is able to cultivate diligence, etc.

Knowing oneself means I have such faith, precepts, etc.
Knowing the assembly means ká¹£atriyas, brahmins, etc.
Knowing the noble and humble is as stated in the text: Good sons!
There are two kinds of people:
First, those with faith; second, those without faith.
Bodhisattvas should know that those with faith are good, and those without faith are not called good.
Faith is also of two kinds:
First, going to the monastery; second, not going.
Going to them is good, not going to them is not considered good.

In this way, paying homage, listening to the Dharma, contemplating the meaning, practicing as taught, seeking the vehicle of the hearers, and dedicating to the Great Vehicle, each one is the same as the first two. Therefore, the conclusion says, Dedicating to the Great Vehicle is the most supreme and good.
It does not bring up the names of noble and humble, the meaning is saying:
The good ones are noble, the bad ones are humble, then each later one is more noble than the previous one.
The commentary says Brahma is purity, the third is concluding the original name.
This uses the momentum of the VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra to harmonize the different explanations, all for the general meaning.
In the previous explanation of the name there are three explanations, now saying Brahma is purity, this is the previous general explanation, taking the name by holding the occupation.
But below it takes the upper two natures and purifies them, this is the previous true realm as Brahma.
Since the true realm is the cause of pure practice, one cannot speak of purity outside of practice; purity is precisely practice.
It also says the purity of practice is the purity of wisdom. The purity of practice is precisely the cause of wisdom; one cannot take wisdom alone as practice.
The purity of wisdom is the purity of mind. It is not merely taking the true realm as purity.
The purity of mind is the purity of all merits. It unifies the previous Nirvana as the cause of pure cultivation, and now the cause is also pure.
Up to the accomplishment of Buddhahood, the merit returns to the practice. It returns to the pure practice.
Since the fruit of Nirvana is accomplished by pure practice, how can one unilaterally say that Nirvana is pure?
This shows that practice is precisely purity.

This is the text.
The textual style is already known.
Why is it that when the nature is pure, one attains the purity of practice, and so on?
It means that practice arises in accordance with principle, and when practice is accomplished, wisdom is established.
Because wisdom is established, one sees the original purity of the mind.
Since the mind is the master, what merit is not accomplished?
Therefore, they depend on each other.
The commentary says However, the previous faith and below, the fourth is distinguishing the differences from the previous, which can be known.

The fourth is the foul smell of its own characteristics. This shows the five kinds of impurity, which the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom says: The practitioner, abiding in pure precepts, single-mindedly practices and contemplates the five kinds of impure characteristics:
The first is the impurity of seeds, referring to the body formed from the seeds of consciousness caused by one's own karma and the essence and blood of one's parents.
The second is the impurity of the dwelling place, being below the womb's digestive organ and above the reproductive organ in the mother's womb.
The third is the impurity of the self-nature, referring to the body being composed of thirty-six substances.

The fourth is the impurity of its own characteristics, also called the impurity of external characteristics, referring to the constant flow of nine orifices: the eyes produce tears, the ears produce earwax, the nose produces mucus, the mouth produces saliva, and the urinary and anal tracts constantly discharge impurities.
The fifth is the ultimate impurity, after the cessation of breath, the body becomes bloated, foul-smelling, and putrid, becoming extremely disgusting.
The current commentary has already secretly matched [the five kinds of impurity with the five aggregates].

The commentary states because the six kinds of seeds and abodes are all disgusting - the five kinds of impurity are all disgusting, the above correspond to intrinsic nature and intrinsic characteristics, and the below correspond to ultimate, therefore this pair is mentioned, and the other three are taken as equal.
As for all are disgusting, the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom has verses concluding all five.
The verse on the one kind of seed states this body's seed is impure, not some wonderful treasure, not born from whiteness, but only comes out from the foul path.
The verse on the abode states this body is foul-smelling, not born from among flowers, nor from champak, nor does it come out from a jeweled mountain.
The verse on intrinsic nature states the substance of earth, water, fire, and wind can transform into impurity, even if one empties the ocean to wash this body, it cannot be made fragrant and clean.
The verse on the external appearance states various impure things fill the body, constantly flowing out without stopping, like a leaking bag filled with things.
The fifth concluding verse says, Carefully observe this body, it will surely return to death. Difficult to control, without gratitude, betraying kindness like a child.
The conclusion says, The practitioner cultivating this contemplation perfects the thought of destroying the inverted view of purity.

The commentary states Among the three kinds of discrimination, this is discrimination of self-nature. This is the second chapter of the Abhidharmasamuccaya-vyÄkhyÄ, which says, There are three kinds of discrimination, namely discrimination of self-nature, discrimination of recollection, and discrimination of conceptualization. The various kinds of discrimination are assigned to the other two.
As for discrimination of self-nature, it refers to the discrimination of the specific characteristics of the various conditioned phenomena that are currently being experienced.
As for discrimination of recollection, it refers to the discrimination of the conditioned phenomena that were experienced in the past, recollecting them.
As for discrimination of conceptualization, it refers to the discrimination of the conditioned phenomena that are not directly perceived in the past, present, and future, contemplating them.

As for the seven discriminations, the treatise says: There are also seven kinds of discrimination, namely spontaneous discrimination of the object, discrimination with characteristics, discrimination without characteristics, seeking discrimination, examining discrimination, defiled discrimination, and undefiled discrimination.

The first discrimination refers to the five groups of consciousness, which are without different discriminations like the characteristics of the object, because they operate spontaneously with regard to their own objects.
Discrimination with characteristics refers to the two kinds of discrimination of intrinsic nature and recollection, because they grasp the various characteristics of past and present objects.
Discrimination without characteristics refers to the discrimination that seeks future objects and activities.
The remaining discriminations all take the discrimination of conceptualization as their intrinsic nature.
Why is this so?
Because of conceptualization, sometimes there is seeking, sometimes there is examining, sometimes there is defilement, and sometimes there is non-defilement, due to various discriminations.

The undefiled discriminating discernment is good or indeterminate, that is, the discrimination of escape, the discrimination of nonhatred, the discrimination of non-harmfulness, or that which arises associated with any of the good dharmas such as faith, or that which arises as the discrimination of the various postures, arts and crafts, and transformations.

Sleep is indeterminate means the above commentary says, Sleep refers to sleepiness, causing the body to be not at ease, with obscurity and brevity as its nature, and the obstruction of contemplation as its activity.
It means that in the state of sleep, the body is not at ease, the mind is extremely dark and inferior, and it operates through a single door.

It is now shown that sleep is not without substance and function, and in the state of mindlessness, this name is provisionally established.

The mind is concentrated and focused, and it is not confused, therefore it is said that confusion is distinguished by being in concentration.
Enlightenment is extensive in its objects, and cannot be called concise, therefore it is said that conciseness is distinguished by the time of enlightenment.
Therefore, sleep has two aspects, showing that it has a separate substance, and it must rely on the mind.
There are five states without mind:

As for saying light sleep has dreams, it distinguishes from deep sleep, showing that this sleep is included in the indeterminate, because it is common to good and evil, and because dreams are good and evil.

The commentary says these ten are mental activities and so forth. It means that since it explains the mental faculty, and the mental faculty is the mind king, it speaks of the mental activities because the mental activities are not apart from the king.

As for using the five universal mental activities to investigate, the fifth chapter of the VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄsiddhi-Å›Ästra says: Namely, contact, attention, feeling, conceptualization, and volition. Because they can definitely be obtained in all minds, they are called universal mental activities.

Moreover, because they possess the four universals, namely: 1. Universality in the three natures, 2. Universality in the nine levels, 3. Universality in all times when there is mind, 4. Universality in all states.
Namely, because they are mental activities in any state. Contact is the most superior in combining, so it is listed first in the treatise.

Attention is the same as the mind, a compound word with the same meaning.
Or it is the attention that occurs simultaneously, with the neighboring one being superior.
What is CONTACT?

Contact is the transformation of the three into discrimination, which causes mind and its activities to touch the object. Its nature is that of supporting such activities as feeling, conceptualization, and volition. Its activity is that of supporting feeling, conceptualization, volition, etc.
The three are the organ, the object, and consciousness. They are mutually corresponding, and therefore they are called the three.
Contact is born in dependence on them and causes them to unite, and for that reason it is said to be of them.
In the state of union of the three, there is a power to generate dharmas that are mental activities, and this is called transformation.
Contact is similar to that power and is therefore called discrimination.

When contact is generated by the power of the transformation of the organ, it has as its object the consciousness that has as its object the object of the organ. Therefore the Abhidharmasamuccaya, etc., only speak of the discrimination of the transformation of the organ. Contact causes all mind and activities to unite and touch the same object, and this is the nature of contact.
Since it is similar to the power that generates mental activities, its activity is that of supporting feeling, etc.
What is FEELING?

Feeling is the experience of objects that are agreeable, disagreeable, or neither. Its nature is that of receiving, and its activity is that of arousing craving, because it can arouse desires for union, separation, or neither one.
What is conception?
Conception is the nature of grasping images of objects, with the function of establishing various names and expressions.
This means that only by establishing the characteristics of the scope of objects can one subsequently give rise to various names and expressions.
What is volition?ğŸ”½Volition is the nature of causing the mind to create activities, with the function of engaging the mind in wholesome and other [categories].
This means that it can grasp the characteristics of the correct causes, etc., of objects, and drive one's own mind to create wholesome and other [activities].
These last four do not have the six explanations.
The commentary says:
Because the names are mostly the same as the universal mental factors, attention is investigated throughout the ten sections, following the treatise and explaining first.
The commentary says The above four sections are also each one aggregate, referring to the five universal mental factors mentioned above.

From the perspective of the sutra, volition is the aggregate of formations, conception is the aggregate of conception, cold, heat, hunger, and thirst are the eleven contacts belonging to the aggregate of form, feelings such as pain are the aggregate of feelings, and attention is also the aggregate of formations.
However, touch is common to both body and mind. Above, it was said that cold, etc., must accompany the mind, so it belongs to the universal mental factors.
Now, it is about bodily touch, so it belongs to form.
If so, bodily touch is in the stage of the five consciousnesses. Why is it now in the manas?
The answer:
There are three meanings.
First, by the meaning of association, it means that manas and the five have the same object.
Second, because manas is strong in function, it has the same object.
Third, because manas has the touch of pleasure in the extremely blissful realm, and has mental suffering in the extremely miserable realm.
The above cold and heat can be understood by analogy.
Among the above three meanings, the first two are about touch, and the last one also clarifies feeling.
Cold is the touch of coolness.

Now, when it is said to be contact, it is named after the effect.
Therefore, the treatise says: 'These are all named after the effect based on the cause.'
The commentary says:
Warmth and desire are called cold. Heat is based on cold. Cold and heat are mutually opposed. The meaning also has desire, so these four are all mental actions.
The commentary says: The last four are feelings, which are suffering, pleasure, worry, and joy.
However, the holy teachings explain feelings differently in terms of their inclusion and exclusion.

Sometimes they are divided into three: suffering, pleasure, and neutrality.

Experiencing disagreeable objects and oppressing the body and mind is called the feeling of suffering.
Experiencing neutral objects and neither oppressing nor delighting the body and mind is called the feeling of neither suffering nor pleasure.
Or it is divided into five: suffering, pleasure, sorrow, joy, and equanimity.
The VijÃ±aptimÄtratÄ-Å›Ästra says: All pleasant feelings that are associated with the five consciousnesses are simply called pleasure.
If associated with mental consciousness, if in the preliminary stage of the desire realm and first two dhyÄnas, it is called joy, because it only delights the mind.
If in the fundamental stage of the first two dhyÄnas, it is called joy, because it delights both body and mind.
If in the preliminary stage or fundamental stage of the third dhyÄna, it is called pleasure, because it is tranquil and heavy, and there is no discrimination.
